awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SUPER: Search for high-temperature superconductivity in heterostructured two-dimensional organic materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
The project sets the goal to design and fabricate single- and multi-layer organic materials which can host superconductivity, potentially at room temperature and ambient pressure. Obviously, this discovery would be a revolution across all technologies but in particular in microelectronics and energy transfer and generation. But even if this grand goal is not achieved, the development of the protocols for growth of multilayered organic materials with programmed functionality enables applications in semiconductor and renewable energy industries, optics and lasing. On the educational side, the project brings into the PI’s group an entirely new area of research linked to organic chemistry. Through group meetings and direct participation in the research, graduate and undergraduate students broaden their knowledge and expertise in organic and quantum chemistry, fields that are typically not part of physics education. The project supports training of undergraduate students in organic chemistry, semiconductor processing and transport, magnetic and optical measurements. It also creates opportunities for undergraduate research during summer, to be offered to the students from Department of Chemistry, thus exposing them to many aspects of physics lab. This engagement makes students ready for future collaborative multi-disciplinary work in industrial and academic environment.

Technical Abstract: 
The research team uses the state-of-the-art method of organic molecular beam epitaxy (OMLE) to fabricate several series of organic heterostructured materials anticipated to have superconducting properties at high temperatures. OMLE allows to construct unique molecular intra-layer and inter-layer arrangements inaccessible by standard methods. They include self-assembled monolayers and multilayers made from aromatic molecules such as picene, chrysene, NTCDI, and anchored fullerenes in the configuration of field-effect transistor, which allows to inject carriers by adjusting the gate potential. Molecules with donor and acceptor properties are mixed to imitate molecular arrangements in charge-transfer organic superconductors.  The physical properties of materials are characterized by transport and magnetic measurements in the range 1.5-300 K in the PI’s lab. The growth of the materials is monitored by in-situ spectroscopic ellipsometry. The charge states, electronic band formation, charge-transfer and optical properties are studied using University of Utah shared facilities: x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, optical absorption, and Raman spectroscopies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes

Intellectual Merit

Publications: Two papers supported by the grant have been accepted for publication in Physical Review B. Additionally, we have enough material for several more papers, which will acknowledge grant support. Some of these have already been posted as arXiv articles.
Patent: The PI is in the process of submitting a patent application based on his discovery of a quantum computer emulator using conventional electronic components. Two graduate students, Hassam Ghazali and Samuel Feldman, along with undergraduate student Mason Cochella, are co-applicants on this submission.
Development of Infrastructure: A closed-cycle, He-free system has been delivered and is being installed in the PI’s lab. Grant funding served as seed money for a successful proposal to the University of Utah Research Instrumentation Fund. The system will support multiple research groups at UU. The PI’s group designed and built a custom electron beam evaporator that enables metal film deposition on substrates cooled to liquid nitrogen temperatures, with angle control, all without breaking vacuum. The PI’s group also designed the Single Layer Molecular Epitaxy (SLAME) reactor. Its main components have been built or purchased, and a spectroscopic ellipsometer for the reactor has been acquired and tested.

Broader Impact

The grant has supported one short-term postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduate students. These students have been trained in low-noise electronics and data acquisition, nanofabrication, vacuum and deposition techniques, and software packages such as LabVIEW, Autodesk Inventor, and LTspice.

In addition to his teaching duties, the PI has led a weekly study group on quantum computing, open to all students in the department. He also serves as a moderator at the University of Utah Undergraduate Research Symposium and as a reviewer of undergraduate research proposals.

 


Last Modified: 04/06/2025
Modified by: Andrey Rogachev

Project Outcomes


Intellectual Merit




Publications: Two papers supported by the grant      have been accepted for publication in Physical Review B.      Additionally, we have enough material for several more papers, which will      acknowledge grant support. Some of these have already been posted as arXiv articles.
Patent: The PI is in the process of      submitting a patent application based on his discovery of a quantum      computer emulator using conventional electronic components. Two graduate      students, Hassam Ghazali and Samuel Feldman, along with undergraduate      student Mason Cochella, are co-applicants on this submission.
Development of Infrastructure: A closed-cycle, He-free system      has been delivered and is being installed in the PIs lab. Grant funding      served as seed money for a successful proposal to the University of Utah      Research Instrumentation Fund. The system will support multiple research      groups at UU. The PIs group designed and built a custom electron beam      evaporator that enables metal film deposition on substrates cooled to      liquid nitrogen temperatures, with angle control, all without breaking      vacuum. The PIs group also designed the Single Layer Molecular Epitaxy      (SLAME) reactor. Its main components have been built or purchased, and a      spectroscopic ellipsometer for the reactor has been acquired and tested.


Broader Impact


The grant has supported one short-term postdoctoral researcher, two graduate students, and several undergraduate students. These students have been trained in low-noise electronics and data acquisition, nanofabrication, vacuum and deposition techniques, and software packages such as LabVIEW, Autodesk Inventor, and LTspice.


In addition to his teaching duties, the PI has led a weekly study group on quantum computing, open to all students in the department. He also serves as a moderator at the University of Utah Undergraduate Research Symposium and as a reviewer of undergraduate research proposals.
